title: Express generator starter code incompatible when named pipes are used as ports
body:
I just discovered that the starter code produced by the express generator does not interact well when ports aren't defined as numerical values, but rather as named pipes (e.g. through IISNode on Microsoft Azure Web Sites)

Specifically the line in bin/www (line 15 or so):

```javascript
var port = parseInt(process.env.PORT, 10) || 3000;
```

Removing the call to parseInt appears to resolve this issue.

title: Wildcard in route parameter regexp
body:
Route `'/:username([a-z][a-z-]*)'`
Route `'/:username([a-z][a-z-]*)/:project([a-z][a-z0-9-]*)'`

URL `/someone/project`

Expectation is that the second route should match.
Actual result is the first route matches because the * is considered as all the things rather than "zero or more" `[a-z-]`.

getting 'command not found' after I run 'npm install -g express' as root and then run 'express'.
body:
Hi,

On Mac OSX I am getting 'command not found' after I run 'npm install -g express' as root and then run 'express'. express is in /usr/local/lib/node_modules.

I certainly tried sudo npm install -g express. And I also enabled the root user and ran 'npm install -g express' as the root user - to no avail. I also downloaded the latest node/npm package from nodejs.org and tried again, but no success.

I imagine there is an error log file somewhere that will tell me something, but I don't know where to look.

Do you have any suggestions for me?

title: Cannot include bare colons or forward slashes in Content-Type header
body:
The media typer has problems if you have a colon or forward slash in the value you set for the Content-Type header.  If you include any of those in the supplemental information after the semicolon, the media typer will throw an error like:

```
TypeError: invalid parameter format
    at Object.parse (/Users/duhrer/Source/rtf/unified-listing/node_modules/express/node_modules/media-typer/index.js:186:11)
```

This causes problems when following [the best practices for JSON Schema](http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-core.html#anchor34) and setting a value like:

```
Content-Type: application/my-media-type+json; profile=http://example.com/my-hyper-schema#
```

This only happens with the Content-Type header, you can set the exact same value for an arbitrary header without problems.  I suspect it has to do with the character set handling.

I see the problem in 4.10.6.  This was not a problem in earlier versions of Express (both 3.x and earlier versions of 4.x).  I will do a bit of testing to confirm when it was introduced.

title: How to use express-static
body:
I just added the issue [Due to NodeJs Express static mapper, TM Design allows download of static files](https://github.com/TeamMentor/TM_4_0_Design/issues/206) to my currently project, and although it is an obvious think not to do, it was really easy to expose a lot more files that I wanted to.

In order to mitigate this and to understand better what type of guidance we should be providing, here are a couple questions:

* Is there a way to limit the type of files provided?
* Is there a way to alert the user that the 'root' of the project is now available to the world (vs just some folder)?
* Are there guidance docs/wiki-pages, etc.. that already cover this?
* Are there unit-tests (focused on this scenario) that I can add to my project (to detect and confirm the scale of the exposure)?

title: Details of "Fixed directory traversal vulnerabilities in express.static."
body:
I noticed that on http://expressjs.com/advanced/security-updates.html there is a line about **Fixed directory traversal vulnerabilities in express.static.**

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/656739/5643930/ea46a7d2-9655-11e4-9017-17bd03fd4bbe.png)

But when I tried to find more details, I was not able to locate a good article/issue/blog/unit-test on the topic.

I'm currently running on '4.10.7' and would like to have a way to check if my server(s) are vulnerable to this issue

Could you point me to the commit that fixed the issue and more details about this issue?

ETag should not be generated for no-store
body:
Cache-Control: no-store does not allow the User-Agent to consult anything for caching, as it does not allow caching at all.
This is opposed to no-cache where ETag can be consulted and compared against a HEAD request.

title: Option to disable ETag for certain routes?
body:
There's a need to disable ETag for certain routes, where it is a GET but the data may still change between requests - and it is mandatory to have no caching on it.

Currently the ETag processing is done after the user's code for the response, so there's no way to remove it *after* express has added it.

Now if we add a `Cache-Control: no-store`, the client will surely ignore the ETag, but then the ETag is generated for nothing, and it's an extra CRC or MD5 call which can be spared.

So I think there's a need to make the ETag conditional also on the existence of a "no-store".

title: Memory usage
Add ability to set 'json spaces' on res.json
body:
Currently ````json spaces```` can only be set at an application level, but it would be nice to be able to override that setting on the response level. For example, in my situation I'd like the root of an API route to pretty print JSON (````app.set('json spaces', 2)````), but an actual response to be minified (````app.get('json spaces', 2)````.  

I [found a way](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27446799/dynamically-change-json-spacing-with-express-js/27447385#27447385) to get around this by setting the ````json spaces```` on a response as so:

````
res
   .set("Content-type", "application/json; charset=utf-8")
   .send(JSON.stringify(data, null, 2));
````

This works well, but it would be nice to set ````json spaces```` directly on ````res.json```` in the same way you can set something like ````Content-type````. This PR allows you to do this - for example:

````
res
   .set("json spaces", 2)
   .json(data);
````
If ````json spaces```` is not set on a given ````response```` it falls back to the application's ````json spaces```` setting.
